G.L. c. 212, \u00a7\u202f4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, and the cause of action sounds in negligence under Massachusetts common law.

G.L. c.\u202f223, \u00a7\u202f1.proposition: Venue lies properly in Hampden County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the acts and omissions giving rise to this claim occurred within this county.

Jupin\u202fv.\u202fKask, 447\u202fMass.\.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, all persons owe a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid creating conditions likely to cause foreseeable injury to others. See Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006); Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).

Glidden\u202fv.\u202fMaglio, 430\u202fMa.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, all persons owe a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid creating conditions likely to cause foreseeable injury to others. See Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006); Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).

O\u2019Sullivan\u202fv.\u202fShaw, 431\u.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining and storing equipment—including the aluminum ladder—on property jointly used or accessible to Plaintiff. See O’Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (2000) (land possessors owe a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors); Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).

Mounsey\u202fv.\u202fEllard, 363\u202fMa.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining and storing equipment—including the aluminum ladder—on property jointly used or accessible to Plaintiff. See O’Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (2000) (land possessors owe a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors); Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).

Kent\u202fv.\u202fCommonwealth, 437\u202.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s property damage. See Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312 (2002); Clohessy v. Bachelor, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 108 (1984).

Clohessy\u202fv.\u202fBachelor, 18\u202f.raw_text: Clohessy v. Bachelor, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 108 (1984)
Clohessy\u202fv.\u202fBachelor, 18\u202f.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s property damage. See Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312 (2002); Clohessy v. Bachelor, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 108 (1984).

Lev\u202fv.\u202fBeverly\u202fEnterprise.raw_text: Lev v. Beverly Enterprises–Massachusetts, Inc., 457 Mass. 234 (2010)
Lev\u202fv.\u202fBeverly\u202fEnterprise.proposition: The harm to Plaintiff was foreseeable; a reasonable person would have anticipated that an unsecured aluminum ladder leaning against a fence near a parking area could fall and cause damage during wind gusts. See Lev v. Beverly Enterprises–Massachusetts, Inc., 457 Mass. 234 (2010); Poskus v. Boston Hous. Auth., 406 Mass. 817 (1990).

Poskus\u202fv.\u202fBoston\u202fHous.\u2.raw_text: Poskus v. Boston Hous. Auth., 406 Mass. 817 (1990)
Poskus\u202fv.\u202fBoston\u202fHous.\u2.proposition: The harm to Plaintiff was foreseeable; a reasonable person would have anticipated that an unsecured aluminum ladder leaning against a fence near a parking area could fall and cause damage during wind gusts. See Lev v. Beverly Enterprises–Massachusetts, Inc., 457 Mass. 234 (2010); Poskus v. Boston Hous. Auth., 406 Mass. 817 (1990).

Restatement\u202f(Second)\u202fof\u202fT.proposition: The Defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law, as described in Restatement (Second) of Torts § 283 (as adopted by Massachusetts courts).

Maillet\u202fv.\u202fATF-David\u202fCorp.proposition: Plaintiff has suffered actual damages as a result of Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to: property damage to her vehicle, payment of insurance deductible, rental car expenses, inconvenience, and loss of use of her vehicle. See Maillet v. ATF-David Corp., 407 Mass. 185 (1990) (recognizing recovery for economic and consequential losses proximately caused by negligence).

G.L.\u202fc.\u202f231,\u202f\u00a7\u202f.proposition: Plaintiff provided notice to Defendant of the dangerous condition before the event, satisfying the notice requirement for foreseeability under G.L. c. 231, § 85, and relevant common law standards.
Award prejudgment and post-judgment interest as provided by G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
